DOC.HEAD: Region Agrees to Work Toward Common Market For Teachers
DOC.TEXT: An agreement billed as the nation's first common market for educators has been signed by officials in seven states seeking to draw talented teachers to the Northeast. ``This must be the most attractive section of the country for teachers if we want to attract the kind of talent we are used to in New England,'' Harold Raynolds Jr., commissioner of education in Massachusetts, said Wednesday after the agreement was signed during a conference here. The pact, which goes into effect April 1, 1990, will loosen the certification restrictions that prohibit teachers from moving across state lines. Under the plan, teachers with a Northeast Regional Credential who move within the region would have two years to fulfill any unmet requirements for certification in their new state of residence. The states in the agreement are Massachusetts, Vermont, Rhode Island, New Hampshire, Maine, Connecticut and New York. New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland and the District of Columbia also were making overtures to join the Northeast compact, said Anne Newton, a director for The Regional Laboratory, a federally funded educational research group which helped to develop the agreement with the Northeast Common Market Project. California also was watching the experiment closely, she said. Teacher representatives heralded the agreement as one more step toward ``professionalizing'' education. ``It's very exciting and very forward-thinking,'' said Rosanne Bacon, president of the 68,000-member Massachusetts Teachers Association. Bacon said the agreement would, among other things, encourage more competitive salaries for teachers, who could move to states which offered them more money or benefits. ``We're going to have an incredible interest in people moving from one area into an area where they are truly needed, and the market will obviously have to reflect that, with higher salaries,'' said Bacon, who teaches at a public high school. With 20 years' teaching experience and two masters degrees, Bacon said she could earn $24,000 more a year if she worked 30 miles away in Connecticut. Raynolds and top educators in other states insisted they were interested in improving teaching in the region, not just in their state. ``We're trying to think and act regionally,'' said Richard P. Mills, Vermont's education commissioner. Not all seven states embraced the agreement wholeheartedly. Maine has agreed to allow teachers to fulfill their requirements in one year, instead of two. Connecticut agreed to accept out-of-state teachers under the terms of the agreement only in vocational classes.
